NORMAN THOMAS TALKS ON
WAR PREVENTION AT
ASSEMBLY

KEEP GOING!

Explains Causes and Preventatives for
War. Discredits Both Armament
and Disarmament as Peace
Preservers

Discrediting both armament
and disarmament as methods for
preserving peace, Jr. Norman
Thomas, executive head, of the
League for Industrial Democracy
and former editor of the World
Tomorrow, declared in his address
at the Assembly last Thursday
that the two main causes of war
are the economic dependence of
one nation upon another, and the
existence in every country of a
national spirit which consists
mainly of hostility for other nations. Mr. Thomas has made an
exhaustive study of the problems
associated with world peace and
is a frequent lecturer at colleges
and public meetings -on the subject.
Armament Not War Preventative

is not a 'peace
guard," the speaker said, "the
World War proved that. European powers were as men sitting
around a table playing poker, with
all of them armed to the limit.
Preparing for war is not a sure
way of preserving peace—too
often we get what we prepare for.
"On the other hand, disarmament is an equally inadequate
method for avoiding war. Disarmament is not compatible with
world conditions. Even if every
nation would 'scrap' its navy and
demobilize its army, peace would
be far from assured for the progress of science has created a paradox. The improvement of the
aeroplane, and discoveries in
chemistry and physics have given
nations new devices_that are convertible into war weapons. Therefore, merely to disarm will not
preserve peace, because poisonous
gases and aeroplanes are more essential to modern warfare than
large armies and navies.
"Armament

War Can't Be Outlawed

The contention that war could
be outlawed is also fallacious. It
is usually considered legal to do
what we can do and ethics is seldom a factor in deciding what we
can do. For example, in the
United States many things are
done that can hardly be construed
as in accordance with either the
Spirit or the letter of the Eighteenth Amendment. The argument
that duelling was abolished by legislation and that war could be
abolished in the same way is incorrect. Duelling died because
sober public opinion disparaged
it. The idea of fighting to avenge
a petty insult lost its popularity.
Wars are seldom fought over
Points of honor. The causes of
modern wars can almost invariably be connected with economic
problems, such as the control of
oil, iron or coal."
Mr. Thomas then explained that
practically every nation is dependent on other nations for some necessities of life. Japan, for instance,. is overpopulated and for

to control Korea. Every other

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 11, 1924
COLLEGE: A MOLD
Large-scale production is cited as the panacea of modern. industry.
Even colleges and universities have grasped the idea as a means of
salvation until, now, educators are branding the college graduate as
identical products from the same mold.
This allegation, in at least a large number of cases, is true. The
raw material, in the form of high and preparatory school graduates, is
gathered rather than selected, is thrown into the maChine ; the wheels
are turned and a stereotyped, heterogeneous finished product is shipped
out into the world. Now and then the machine slips and a few "irregulars" appear but, for the most part, the products of the Maine plant
and the Texas plant are identical.
The causes leading to this situation seem to us to be obvious. Success and failure in the American University are determined solely by
marks. A man takes a text-book, learns what someone else has to say on
a subject, writes this opinion on an examination paper and graduates
with honors without having had an idea of his own. His class-mates
have read the same text-book, have recorded the same opinion, has undergone the same abstinence from reflection. They are all truly products
of the same mold.
The primary purpose of a college education should be to make a
man think for himself. It should not be made what John Stuart Mill
called "a mere contrivance for moulding people to be exactly like one
another." A paragraph appearing in a text-book used by all Hopkins
freshmen reads "A young man properly educated should be able to
. He should not be at the mercy of any new theory
detect a fallacy
which is presented to him in a specious and attractive shape."
We leave the discovery of a remedy to better-trained and more experienced minds than ours. When marks are subordinated rather than
emphasized, when the college man is taught to seek knowledge instead of
taking it as matter of course, when research is introduced on a ,large
scale; in short, when a man is taught to think it will no longer be possible to refer to college graduates as products from the same mold.

IMPORTANT PROBLEMS DISCUSSED IN CIVIL ENGINEERING SEMINARY
Problems of great importance to
the civil engineer are discussed
each week during the seminary hour
of the seniors in the Civil Engineering Department. Each senior is assigned a problem which he must
write up at some length and then
discuss for a half hour before his
fellow-students and the faculty.
This course, which is conducted by
Prof. John H. Gregory, head of
the Civil Engineering Department,
is one of greatest importance to
the young engineer. It teaches him
not only to find and digest all the
available material upon a particular
topic but it also teaches him,
through experience, to express himself while on his feet.
Among the problems already discussed are "New Tests on Compression Members," "The Bearing Value of Soils," "Fatigue of Metals,"
and "A Discussion of the New
Structural Specifications."

INTER-DIOCESAN CONFERENCE
William Gross, Robert Middleton and Ralph Wales, the three
Hopkins men picked as delegates to
the Inter-Dicicesan Conference held
at St. Albans, the National Cathedral in Washington, by the Episcopal Diocese of Maryland, have
brought back a number of new
ideas and are planning to start an
Episcopal Club in the University.
The purpose of the conference
was to bring the Episcopal students
of the universities and colleges in
Maryland and the District of Columbia into closer touch and to
form an organization capable of
providing for conferences to be
held in the future as well as for
starting Episcopal Clubs in colleges
where none had previously existed.
Ralph Wales was elected President of the new organization. Miss
Elizabeth Grassley, of Goucher,
was elected -Vice-President and the
Rev. Ronald Taylor, of the University of Maryland, was made Secretary. All the colleges of Maryland were well represented, delegates being present from Goucher,
Western Maryland, University of
Maryland, St. John's, Washington,
Blue Ridge, Hood, George Washington, and Maryland College for
Women.
Plans are already under way for
the next conference, which will be
held in Baltimore about this time
next year. The size of the conference will be greatly enlarged by
the presence of a number of colleges hitherto unrepresented.

audience, which was composed
largely of Goucher students in philosophy and psychology and a
number of Hopkins students.

COLLEGE: A MOLD
Large-scale production is cited as the panacea of modern. industry.
Even colleges and universities have grasped the idea as a means of
salvation until, now, educators are branding the college graduate as
identical products from the same mold.
This allegation, in at least a large number of cases, is true. The
raw material, in the form of high and preparatory school graduates, is
gathered rather than selected, is thrown into the maChine ; the wheels
are turned and a stereotyped, heterogeneous finished product is shipped
out into the world. Now and then the machine slips and a few "irregulars" appear but, for the most part, the products of the Maine plant
and the Texas plant are identical.
The causes leading to this situation seem to us to be obvious. Success and failure in the American University are determined solely by
marks. A man takes a text-book, learns what someone else has to say on
a subject, writes this opinion on an examination paper and graduates
with honors without having had an idea of his own. His class-mates
have read the same text-book, have recorded the same opinion, has undergone the same abstinence from reflection. They are all truly products
of the same mold.
The primary purpose of a college education should be to make a
man think for himself. It should not be made what John Stuart Mill
called "a mere contrivance for moulding people to be exactly like one
another." A paragraph appearing in a text-book used by all Hopkins
freshmen reads "A young man properly educated should be able to
. He should not be at the mercy of any new theory
detect a fallacy
which is presented to him in a specious and attractive shape."
We leave the discovery of a remedy to better-trained and more experienced minds than ours. When marks are subordinated rather than
emphasized, when the college man is taught to seek knowledge instead of
taking it as matter of course, when research is introduced on a ,large
scale; in short, when a man is taught to think it will no longer be possible to refer to college graduates as products from the same mold.
